text:
PAX HEHMEYER: My
name is Pax Hehmeyer. I'm the senior director
of academic programs here at the Stanford
Engineering Center for Global

and Online Education
at Stanford Online. If you've joined us
before and you're wondering what the Stanford
Engineering Center for Global

and Online Education is, we
changed our name from SCPD, or the Stanford Center for
Professional Development

earlier this year. Instead of SCPD,
we are now CGOE.

So I'll be talking today a
little bit about our credit bearing programs in
artificial intelligence.

And I am also joined by my
colleague Petra Parikova who will be introducing herself.

So hello. Welcome, everybody. Nice to meet you virtually. My name is Petra
Parikova, and I'm

the senior associate director
of our computer science and AI professional programs.

And I will be talking
to you a little bit more about our professional
side of the portfolio. And yeah, we're super excited
that you are here with us.

Hopefully, you will
have a lot of questions. And please keep them coming. We will try to
answer as many as we can throughout this presentation
and also kind of at the end.

To give you a very
quick overview of what we offer at Stanford
Engineering Center for Global

and Online Education, we offer
different options focused on AI for technical
professionals,

also for business
professionals, and also for professionals in health. For the technical
professionals, we actually

have a very, very
thorough portfolio that we'll tell you a
little bit more about. So Pax will be talking
to you a little bit more

about the AI
graduate certificate, and I will talk to
you a little bit more about the AI
professional certificate.

But I did want to also
make sure that you all know that if you want
to preview anything

or if you're just excited
to see what we are covering in our classes, we also
have a lot of content

available on YouTube. So a lot of the classes
that are technical are also available on YouTube. So I did want to give you that
information right up front.

If you are joining us from
different organizations, and maybe you are
less interested

in the technical details
and technical backgrounds

in artificial
intelligence, we also have some offerings
that are specifically geared towards the business.

On the business side
of the portfolio, the big one that has been
developed just recently

is generative AI program that
focuses on technology, business, and society. So not even just business
and applications, but also

kind of ethical considerations
that we cover in this program. Then we have mastering
generative AI

for product innovation. So if we have some product
managers out there or people interested in developing
products or finding

the right market, this might be
the right course to look into. We have building an AI
enabled organization that

covers a little bit more kind
of about how to go around the recent changes
that are coming up,

as well as the AI
driven leadership, how to be a good leader,
and AI UX design essentials.

So this is on the business
side of the portfolio. We will not talk
much about this part.

We will really focus mostly
on the technical aspects. But if you do have some people
who are more interested in this,

please let us know if
you have any questions, and we will try to respond
to those as much as we can. And then also, if
you some health

care professionals,
people working in health care, medicine,
we have AI in health and also applications of
machine learning and medicine,

which is specifically kind
of also geared towards you if you are coming from the
more health background.

And I think with that,
let me also tell you where to find out more.

I encourage you to
go to this site. If you don't want to type
this up in your browser,

we also have a lot of links
available on the platform. So I believe it's on
your top right corner.

You will see this page with
Stanford Online AI courses and programs where you can
explore a little bit more.

A lot of the options
we have here are paid. But as mentioned, we also try
to offer a lot of webinars,

a lot of sessions,
and a lot of material on YouTube if you
want to take a look. But yeah, with
that, I will hand it

hand over back to
Pax, who will tell you more about the graduate
certificate option. PAX HEHMEYER: Thanks, Petra.

And thank you for already
posting some questions. Again, please
continue to ask them.

Just to respond
to one off the bat here is we don't make
the slides available.

But that link that you can
see in your interface, that will take you to a page that has
all the information we're going

to cover today and more too. So you can really go in and dive
into comparing these programs.

So I'm going to talk a little
bit about the AI graduate certificate that's available
through Stanford Online.

So first, to back up, what
is a graduate certificate. So the certificate,
generally speaking,

it is accredited through the
same regional accreditor that accredits Stanford's degrees.

It consists of four
graduate level courses. And these are the actual courses
that are happening on campus.

You take them for credit,
earn a transcript. You take them as an online
student at the same time as

on campus student. So that's usually between
12 and 20 units of work. And you have about three years.

You have up to three years
to complete that certificate. So the cost is on
a per unit basis.

And you can see an estimate
here of what the cost is with this year's tuition. Tuition does come up.

It changes every year along
with it does on Stanford. And that's the core of
the graduate certificate.

So it's a credit-bearing
certificate made up of four credit-bearing courses.

And you have about three
years to complete it. Now just to take a look
at this is a snapshot

of the courses that
are currently available or part of that certificate. And what you'll see
is there are two--

there's actually one required
course, either machine learning, which is CS229, or
Artificial Intelligence

Principles and
Techniques, which is the core introductory
artificial intelligence course available at Stanford
for graduate students.

In addition to that, you can
complete up to three electives. Up to because you could complete
both 229 and 221, both machine

learning and artificial
intelligence principles, artificial intelligence
principles and techniques, and then two electives.

Or you can complete either
CS229 or 221 and two electives.

And there are a lot
of electives in there. You can look through them. And we add more periodically. And we have additional courses
that aren't listed there,

but are related to
artificial intelligence. And if you take one
of those courses, then you can petition
the department

to have it count towards
the certificate as well. So those would be
things like what we're offering this quarter--

large language model
or language modeling from scratch or sometimes
we have a natural language--

I think it's natural language
understanding for speech. So there are different
kinds of courses

as well that aren't listed
here, but that are available. And you can petition
to have it count. So again, what's required are
for graduate level courses.

So what does that actually mean
when I say the actual course? So what happens, the way
we do it is the class

is happening on campus. So we're going to follow
the academic quarter. So spring quarter started today.

Today is the first
day of spring quarter. So there are courses happening
on Stanford's campus.

We have extended a
handful of those-- well, actually up to 70 each quarter-- out to online students.

You enroll as an online student. You're taking the same class. You're responsible for
the same assignments. You're responsible for
the same deadlines.

You're doing the same work
as on campus students, and you're joining
as an online student. So each of those
courses are going

to vary just as they
did at your University. They'll vary by the instructor. Even the same course,
which can be offered

multiple times a year,
may vary a little bit, depending on which
instructor is offering it. Generally, there will be a
mix of written programming

assignments, projects,
exams, problem sets. It'll, again, vary
from course to course.

The lectures themselves usually
are not available for real time interaction. We're recording
them as they happen.

You can live stream
them or you can watch the recording after
the lecture completes at your convenience.

Now, again, just
to remind you, it's the actual Stanford
Graduate course. So you're following
the academic calendar.

So it's not like you can
wait to watch those lectures. You still need to watch
them in a fairly timely way

to make sure you're keeping
up with the coursework and meeting all the deadlines. When you complete
the course, you

do earn a Stanford transcript
and you earn Stanford units.

Now, if you were to be admitted
into a master's degree here at Stanford, you
could apply up to 18

of those units
towards the degree if those units are
relevant to the degree. So obviously, if you're taking
artificial intelligence courses

and maybe pursuing a master's
in English, may not apply. And then second,
of course, you have

to be admitted into the
degree and the final approval for applying those units does
lie with the department itself.

And finally, as you
take these courses or continue to
take these courses, you do need to
earn a B or better.

You're not admitted
into Stanford. You're being approved on
a course by course basis to take these classes. And you do need to
earn a B or better

to continue taking classes
and to earn their certificate.

So let me say a few
more things about it. So maybe taking a step back
and just talking through who

are some of the students
who are interested in this. So it is a very
flexible program. It's not as flexible as the
professional program, which

we'll talk about, but
it is very flexible. Again, you have to follow
the academic deadlines. We follow the academic quarters.

You are following along
with an academic class. And these are intense
graduate level courses. Most students report spending
15 to 25 hours a week

on a single course. They're very intense
technical courses. They're graduate level computer
science, mechanical engineering,
or air and astronautics courses. So they're intense courses. But you have this flexibility.

You're not enrolling
in a degree program. So you don't need to be
continuously enrolled. So maybe you're interested in
taking a course this summer.

You take the course
this summer fall. Come fall quarter, you've
got a big project at work.

You don't need to take a
course in fall quarter. You could enroll again in
the following winter quarter or in spring quarter.

The key thing is you
just need to-- if you're interested in the
certificate, you need to complete
all that coursework by the end of three
years in order

for it to count towards
the certificate. That said, you don't need
to pursue the certificate. You can just take
individual courses,

either within the certificate or
as part of other certificates. So maybe you're not
interested in the certificate.

You just want to take
one or two courses, and then you see
another one or two courses, and another certificate
that you're interested in.

That's fine as well. The thing to note, as I said,
is you have that flexibility.

And so what we're
seeing is we generally see two types of students. There are a lot of students who
come who are maybe already have

an advanced degree. Maybe you already have
a PhD or a master's. Maybe you already have a PhD or
master's in computer science.

But as new developments
happen, you're interested in
refreshing your skills or filling a particular gap that
you had in your PhD program.

Maybe you didn't have
artificial intelligence and you specialize
in something else. And now you see
the demand and you want to come back and study it.

Well, that's a
perfect use case here. You come in, you take one or
two courses, you fill that gap,

you do some coursework, you
understand the fundamentals--

you learn to understand
those fundamentals. Another example are
students who are maybe earlier or earlier
mid-career, who

are interested maybe in going
back to graduate school. And so they want to see
if graduate school is right for them.

They want to see if
Stanford is right for them. And so they'll take
a handful of courses, and they'll test it out.

And again, these
are the same courses that are happening on campus. So if you're
successful here, that indicates you might be
successful in a graduate program

here or elsewhere. Now, if you're interested
in artificial intelligence,

but you're not quite
ready-- and I'm going to jump into the
prerequisites in a second. We do have other
programs available,

including introductory
programming or foundations of computer science. So these are similar
graduate certificates

that are going to give you the
foundational work in programming and some of the mathematics.

We don't offer all
the prerequisites through Stanford Online. So if you don't have the
background, for instance,

in a lot of the math like
calculus and linear algebra, you may need to look elsewhere
to build up those prerequisites

to build up that knowledge. Let me pause here
for a second to see-- I see questions about
admissions process.

Let me take a look at that.  So these are some
great questions.

So let me keep moving
through because I'm going to talk about the
admissions process very soon.

And so I'll answer
that question. And then I'll come back to this
great question of right now as well about prerequisites.

So in general, if
you're going to be successful in the
graduate courses,

you're going to need
the prerequisites. So there are some
hard prerequisites that everyone needs, which
the first thing is you do

need to confer
bachelor's degree. And you're going
to generally need a GPA of at least 3.0 or better.

Now you're approved on
a course by course basis by the home department
of that course. So each department is going
to set slightly different kind

of baseline prerequisites
that they need for any course that you're going to take there. So when you go to the course
catalog, click on the course,

you can scroll
down, and you should be able to see what
the prerequisites are, the baseline prerequisites for
that particular course are.

Now, in addition to that
baseline, a bachelor's degree with a 3.0 or better,
is that you're also

going to need college
calculus and linear algebra, usually multivariable calculus.

You're going to need to
have probability theory, and you're going to need to have
a strong programming experience. That's going to be
just something that--

that's the baseline
for taking any of these artificial
intelligence courses. Other courses might have
higher requirements.

There might be additional
math or additional specific programming requirements. Again, take a look at
the individual course.

You're not being
admitted into a program. You're being
reviewed and approved on a course by course basis. So we leave it up
to you to review,

make sure you meet
those prerequisites. And so when you're
submitting your application, and the Department
reviews it, they

can see those
prerequisites there. And I see a question about it's
been a long time since you've taken some of those courses.

They will look through
your transcripts. Part of the application
process will be submitting your undergraduate
or graduate transcripts,

and they will review those. And they'll see if you meet the
prerequisites for the course and the general prerequisites
for the department.

And if you do-- and they'll consider
other things. But generally, if
you do, they'll approve you to take the
course, if there's a seat.

But if you haven't
taken it in 10 years, you're going to,
of course, struggle to keep up with the
course material.

So I do recommend
reviewing that material. I think we have some resources
that we link to on our site

where you can review the
calculus, the linear algebra. You can usually use just a
lot of the free resources that

are available out there. Most of the courses will
also have review sessions on some of the core
concepts and material,

including linear algebra and
calculus and probability theory, to get you back up to
speed if you haven't taken

a while because you generally
don't need everything in linear algebra. You may only need
certain portions of it. So they'll highlight
the key aspects

of these different
aspects of math and that you're going to need. And they'll help
you walk through it. But you do want to make sure
you're up to speed on that.

One other thing
I'll say about this is a majority of those
artificial intelligence graduate level courses do
have public facing websites.

You can just Google the
course number, Stanford, and it'll pull it up. And they're going to have more
detail about the prerequisites.

Sometimes they'll even have
some early problem sessions-- or excuse me-- problem
sets that you'll be able to look at to
see how comfortable you

are with the level of the
material before you enroll. And finally, I'll
say, as Petra did,

is that we have a
lot of the lectures as well for these courses
available on our YouTube channel, the Stanford
Online YouTube channel.

So that's another
good way to set a baseline of how much
you need to review

and what the level of
these courses will be. You can go on our Stanford
Online YouTube channel, you can watch some of
the lecture recordings

from machine learning, from
natural language understanding,

from natural language
processing, and from-- what others? We have deep learning. We have a lot of them up there.

Reinforcement learning. So take a look at those. It'll give you a good
sense of the level and the difficulty
of the courses.

So that's all building towards
what the application is. Now again, as I said, you're
not approved for the program.

You're approved on a
course by course basis. You don't need to pursue
the whole certificate. You can just take
individual courses.

You can do as you like
as long as you continue to do well in the courses. So what you'll need to do is go
to our website, Stanford Online,

create account, and then you'll
submit a non-degree option application.

And the core requirements
there is short statement of purpose, some
personal information,

your professional
background, and then your educational background. And that's going to involve your
official University transcripts.

And we want to see
everything, including your undergraduate, your
master's, PhD if you have it.

The most important, of
course, is the undergraduate because that's the
baseline of what you need.

Once you've submitted
that application, it is not reviewed by anyone
until you enroll in a course.

And that's really-- that step
3 is really, really important. So once you've submitted
that application, you go in,

you choose the course
you want to enroll in, and you select enroll now. Your application is on file.

It's submitted. The department will then
submit that application to the department
to review to see

if you meet the requirements
for that particular course. Now let's say you
take that course, you complete that course,
you do well in that course.

Then you can look
at the next quarter you want to enroll in it. You select the next class. You enroll in that class.

We again send your
application to the department. And this time, along with
your Stanford transcripts,

they will review all that. And again, they will review and
either approve or reject you for that next course. So it really is on a
course by course basis.

You're not admitted
into a program. You're not admitted
into Stanford. You're being
approved to take on--

you're being
approved on a course by course basis, one
course at a time. So let me pause here
and see if there's

some other It's a
good questions I see.

Great. And great question about
enrollment periods. So because we're on
the court of process,

enrollment is not continuously
open for these courses. We usually open enrollment
about two months

before the quarter begins. So the next enrollment
period will be for summer.

It opens on April 7, which
is actually next week. So on April 7, our
enrollment will open for summer courses
that are starting in June.

In late July, early August
is when enrollment will open for our autumn quarter courses.

It's only once that enrollment
opens that we really have a finalized schedule,
but you can go to our site.

And we're working on
better ways to show you what the full year schedule is. But generally,
when you come right

before the beginning of the
quarter, you'll be able to see-- excuse me. Right at the beginning
of our enrollment period, you'll be able to
see which courses

are available for
enrollment that year. And then you just
click on enroll. So there are four
enrollment periods.

They start about two months
before the quarter begins. And it's during that
enrollment period

that you can enroll for the
courses for the upcoming quarter. So again, for summer,
it opens on April 7.

And those are for courses
starting in mid June. And for autumn quarter, it
will be opening late July,

early August for courses
starting in late September. And you can go to our website
and go to graduate programs

and courses. And you can see our
full academic calendar, which shows the enrollment
periods for all the quarters.

And we will have
our one for 20-- for the next academic
year should be up in the next couple of weeks.

PETRA PARIKOVA: And Pax
a follow up question about this was about
classes being available.

And some folks are wondering
why some of the enrollments might be closed right now. So can you tell
a little bit more

about what to expect from
the upcoming quarters and when classes open? PAX HEHMEYER: All courses
are closed for enrollment

right now because the
enrollment period close. The quarter has begun. We closed is a great question. So if you're a
matriculated students,

their enrollment
period goes all the way through basically the first
three weeks of the quarter because they can swap
and shop courses.

The enrollment for non-degree
students opens earlier, but it closes about two
weeks before the quarter.

And the reason for that
is that, as I said, everyone is reviewed
every single time they enroll in a course. So we need that time
period to review

all the applications to make
sure all the paperwork is in place. So right now, no
enrollment is open.

Spring quarter has
already started. We're not accepting any more
applications for courses that's

starting in the spring quarter. But next week, enrollment and
will open for summer quarter.

And you can then enroll
in summer quarter courses. Yeah, that's a good question.

PETRA PARIKOVA:
And then there were more questions about
the prerequisites and what they need to submit.

And if some specific
kind of document would work, if they
should have great grades,

or if it's sufficient
just to submit a transcript, and learning more
about the step 2 over here.

PAX HEHMEYER: Yeah, this
is a great question. So I see-- so let me just--
question that just came in.

The application process
is going to be different depending on the program
you're applying for. So the application
process I just

lay it out is for any credit
bearing course that you want to take or any graduate
certificate that you're

pursuing. Right now, we're focusing on
the I graduate certificate, but we have 30 graduate
certificates that you could

pursue and about 200 courses
a year that you could take, not just in artificial
intelligence.

In terms of the
prerequisites, so it will depend on the
specific prerequisite.

But generally, for
a math prerequisite, the departments will
want to see something

on an official transcript. So something from an accredited
University here or abroad.

And they're going to want to
see a grade usually on that. So if you did a Coursera
on linear algebra,

they're probably not
going to accept a Coursera on linear algebra. But they would take a
linear algebra class

in your undergraduate
transcript. For programming
experience, they're usually much more flexible
because a lot of people

develop that through their work. So if you have a strong
background otherwise,

but you don't have any
programming courses on your transcript, but you can
explain either through your work

experience or through
your statement of purpose, how you meet those
programming prerequisites, then they will often consider
you for these courses.

So for instance, if you have
a background in physics, but you've been working as a
programmer for the past four

years, and you're self-trained
and Python and C++ and et cetera, et cetera, they'll
generally consider that.

But for the math
courses, they're going to want to see
something on your transcript for those particular courses.

It will depend on
the department too. Some departments are
very strict about that. They're going to want to see it.

The requirement, interestingly,
that most students get caught up on is multivariable calculus.

They're going to want to see
over a year of college level calculus on your certificate.

But again-- excuse me
on your transcripts. But it's going to depend
on the department. Some departments will be
a little bit more flexible

on that. So-- yeah. PETRA PARIKOVA: And then I saw
a couple more questions maybe

about a graduate program. One of them, Pax, is about being
abroad and being able first

to apply, and second kind
of being able to follow. So maybe we have people
in Europe or Asia,

and they are not sure if they
will be able to participate. And yeah, if they will have
some classmates maybe even

from other countries
than the US. PAX HEHMEYER: Yeah,
great question. So this is a global program.

So we do have students
from all over the world. Now the majority of our
students are located in the US, but we do have students
from all over the world.

And you can apply from
pretty much anywhere.

And so yes, you can do
it if you're in Europe, you can do it if
you're in Canada.

I think the caveat here
is that, obviously, there can be challenges.

The ability to take an actual
class that's happening on campus is both an opportunity
and a challenge.

It's an opportunity
because you are literally taking the same class as
on campus students are. You're following along
with the same material.

You're attending office
hours, usually on Zoom to talk to TAs to get answers.

You're posting on
the same forums where they're posting questions
for the teaching team.

The challenge, of
course, is that you might be in a different
timeline-- timeline-- time zone. And so it can be a
challenge to join

those Zoom sessions, et cetera. Usually, the teaching
teams do the best they can to accommodate
different time zones and work

schedules because most people
are actually also working full time. So even if you're local and
you may not be able to attend

anything between
9:00 AM and 5:00 PM. So there can be
challenges around that.

The teaching teams
do their best. We do have a pretty
generous drop policy, which is can drop up to the third week
of the course for a full tuition

refund minus, right now,
$100 processing fee. A drop processing fee. So what would happen is we would
encourage you to join in that.

Say you're going to take
a course this summer, you join that first week-- and in the summer, it's
the end of the second week

because summer is
a shorter quarter. But you join that first week,
you take a look at the syllabus, you take a look at the
available office hours.

Maybe you ask some questions
from the teaching team about availability
of things and how

it might work for you as
a student in, say, Germany or in Japan.

And then if you can't do it,
then you drop the course. But generally, they'll
make accommodations,

and they'll work it out
for students even overseas. So it is possible overseas. We have plenty of
students who do it.

But again, as would
be expected, there can be challenges at doing
it from a different time zone or while you're
working full time.

And so-- and there's
not necessarily

a recency requirement. They're going to
look at-- and I see these questions about
how recently you took the prerequisite.

Generally, they're not going
to look at how recently you took the prerequisite. There could be
exceptions to that.

But I would say,
as a general rule, they're not going
to look at, OK, you

did it 10 years ago,
it's not acceptable. But they will expect that if
you've done it 10 years ago, that you are going to
review it and be up to speed

when you join the course. So the burden will
fall more on you

to make sure that
you're up to speed and you review that
crucial course material. Again, a really
valuable resource,

especially for a lot of
these artificial intelligence graduate courses, is to go
and review the public facing

website, if it's available. And you can get a sense of
what the problem sets are. They'll often have
review material

or highlight what part
of a particular math is really important
for the course. And that's something you can
start doing even before you--

as soon as you submit that
application and request to enroll in the
course, you can go in and start reviewing just
to get a sense of what's

going to be involved. Course deadlines are going to
be in the Pacific time zone.
It follows Stanford's deadlines. We're in California.

PETRA PARIKOVA: And Pax,
maybe one last question. I did see a few people
interested in a master's degree

or kind of following up and
learning more or maybe getting admitted to Stanford.

As a graduate student
at some point, does this help, or how
would how would you think about the differences?

PAX HEHMEYER: Yeah, so a
couple of things to note. As I said earlier, if you take
courses as a non-degree student,

you can apply up to
18 of those units towards a relevant
master's degree if you're admitted
into the degree

and pending final
department approval. And again, those have
to be relevant units. A fair number of
students do do that.

Is being a non-degree
student a benefit? It doesn't hurt, but it's
not like a fast track

into the master's degree. The master's degrees at Stanford
are incredibly competitive. They obviously have
a lot of students

who are coming
directly from Stanford applying to those degrees or who
have backgrounds at Stanford. So the non-degree
courses, again, you

can submit that transcript,
your Stanford transcript along with your
other transcripts as part of your master's
degree application.

But it's not a special
gateway or backdoor into the master's program. You'd be considered along
with all the other applicants,
